Hiya,

> "this isn't a REST problem".

"Nina Jeliazkova" <jeliazkova.nina@...> wrote:
> Well, it should be, otherwise a distributed architecture is largely
> useless.

Hmm. Sounds like you underestimate the usefulness of the massively
distributed architecture called Internet. :)

> Unless we are assuming any REST system is an isolated server
> or server farm, running under single authority, and all potential
> users and clients are aware of it and love to read its documentation.

The ambiguity of REST/HTTP is exactly why it *is* so powerful as a concept.
Yes, you have to work a little harder on the application semantics and the
glue of the ontology layer, but it comes with the amazing bonus of all the
goodness of WWW. Surely, we can't ignore its success? It's the ease of
working with it, of setting it up, and the ambigous nature of each request
(that can be tunneled through anything) and the constraints on them (for
cacheability, etc.) that makes that possible.

> Finding resources is critical part of any network architecture. If I
> do not know nothing of Amazon, and there is no any search engine
> available,  how I am supposed to find where to buy online books? Even
> how I am supposed to know I _could_ buy books online?

But why are you raising these what-if questions? Do you have some scenarios
that you are concretely struggeling with, or are good examples of HTTP gone
bad? I fear I do not understand "what if there are no search engines",
because there are.

> Well, we do roughly the same, each resource describing itself with
> RDF, according to a specific ontology. But I would not say this is the
> mainstream approach.

Depends on where you dip your toe. But even if that was true, does that
make it wrong?

Regards,

Alex

--0015174be5a2f32fd504b5a0026c
